title: Aspect Ratio Fix
description: Fix for browser that don't yet support aspect-ratio.
content:
Since Safari doesn’t support aspect-ratio yet:

  aspect-ratio: 16 / 9;  @supports (not (aspect-ratio: 16 / 9)) {    position: relative;    padding-bottom: calc(9 / 16 * 100%);    height: 0;    img {      position: absolute;    }  }

title: Quick Image Manipulations
description: Random snippets for image manipulation.

headers.text: Script for resize and creating source sets

content:
This will probably updated, when I run into more practical solutions.

Script for resize and creating source sets

Simple deno script for creating and optimising a set of images. Needs to be adapted to your needs, but maybe it’s helpful to you:

https://git.sr.ht/~jshsj/jshsj-haus/tree/master/item/public/content/utils/images.ts

Resize a directory of images

  • Download ImageMagick
  • Run mogrify -resize [w] *.jpg

Tool Recommendations

  • Squoosh - Resize and optimse an image in your browser. Built by Google.
  • Pixlr - Edit images in your browser. Has some nice features, is fairly cheap and easy to use.

title: Writing userstories
description: A mini template for writing user stories.
content:
A classic user story

As , I would like to [, so ]

Role needs to be the person, that profits from this. Might be the customer, might be your boss.

Alternatives

  • To achieve as , I would like to .
  • As , I would like , because
  • As , I would like .

https://1qtspv2a8qad3nf2xr3pzat3-wpengine.netdna-ssl.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/10/HW-Story-Splitting-Flowchart.pdf

title: Fluid dynamic typography
description: Optimise your fonts by only providing what's needed.
content:
Explanation

Modular scales and fluid typography scales are not very new, although still not widely popular. They have their upsides and downsides, but I like them.

The basic idea is, that they scale with the devices viewport. Larger viewports have larger fonts (and spacing).

The scale is not linear, but modular, which is supposed to create a more harmonic visual effect. Read more about it under Inpspirations.

Script

This is script I wrote to generate my fluid typography scale.

https://paste.sr.ht/~jshsj/bcb0ca3a49ab0550b8d21e16f9f09025cad7c8d2

Inspiration

Basic explanation and source of inspiration: https://every-layout.dev/rudiments/modular-scale/

I copied and adapted the math from https://www.aleksandrhovhannisyan.com/blog/fluid-type-scale-with-css-clamp/. He also has a online calculator, that’s pretty good, but didn’t completely fit my needs.

title: Font Subsetting
description: Optimise your fonts by only providing what's needed.
content:
Just read this:https://www.sarasoueidan.com/blog/glyphhanger/

TLDR:Run glyphhanger {your(dev)domain} --spider-limit=0 --subset="*.ttf".

  • Replace *ttf with your font’s actual name, if or suffix.
  • Needs to be called in font directory.

title: Performant image loading
description: The basics and a few tips for faster image loading.

headers.text: Add width, height and alt attributes
Create a sourceset and provide sizes
Adding lazy loading and async decoding

content:
Loading images is what we do. Oftentimes. How to do it well is a different thing. Here are a few tips.

The basics

Add width, height and alt attributes

Providing width and height will provide the browser with the necessary information to prevent layout shifts. Getting them is sometimes harder to do, because you’ll either need to set them manually or get them automatically at buildtime or from an API.

Check my deno script at the bottom to see how you can do it yourself.

Providing alt attributes is great for accessibility. That’s your main concern. This will also make for better SEO, so that’s neat.

Create a sourceset and provide sizes

Sourceset combined with sizes will help the browser load the approriate image based on the viewport width.

Generating sourceset is fairly straight forward: Use an online converter or do it yourself. It’s just resizing images, creating the filenames and dumping them into a single string, that looks like this:

/content/images/sources/2021-12-31_flur_neues-namensschild_480.jpg 480w, /content/images/sources/2021-12-31_flur_neues-namensschild_800.jpg 800w, /content/images/sources/2021-12-31_flur_neues-namensschild_1280.jpg 1280w, /content/images/2021-12-31_flur_neues-namensschild.jpg 1440w

The format is: {imagePath}{imageName}{containerWidth*},

The container width is set with the sizes attribute, which looks like this:

(max-width: 480px) 480px, (max-width: 768px) 768px, (max-width: 1280px) 1280px, 1440px

Format is: (max-width:{width}): {containerWidth}.

This practically means: Up to {width} this container will be {containerWidth} wide.

Note: You can use different media queries here, too.

Adding lazy loading and async decoding

Most browser now natively support loading="lazy", which loads images when they are close to the currently shown viewport. Your page will load faster and load images as needed.

Careful: You don’t want to lazyload your “above the fold” image. Set them to loading="eager" instead, so your page will look nice when loading for the first time

decoding="async" will do something similar: Defer the image decoding to a later point in time, so your page can load even if the image is not yet decoded.

A few more tips

  • Cropping your mobile images can be very helpful to reduce the file size while keeping what you want to show. Basically crop your image around what you want to show in a vertical orientation. (Credits go to u/Citrous_Oyster).
  • Resize and optimise your images beforehand. You can do that in your build, manually or through your image cloud service. Only load images in the sizes you actually need and set the quality to around 70% is a good starting point.
  • Load graphics as svg: If you have them, load your logos and graphics as SVGs. They’re smaller in size.
  • If you use a different image host, it might be beneficial to preconnect to that service using: <link rel="preconnect" href="{yourService}" />
  • While you’re at it: You can also preload your header image, if you have one: <link rel="preload" href="{imagePath}" as="image" crossorigin="anonymous">

Links & Further reading

  • https://jakearchibald.com/2021/serving-sharp-images-to-high-density-screens/
  • My example image generating script: https://git.sr.ht/~jshsj/jshsj-haus/tree/master/item/public/content/utils/images.ts

I’ll add to this, when I learn more.

content:
More than just a temporary things.

TBC.

title: Mastery
description: Being truely good at something.
content: Not yet thought.

title: Vulnerability
description: Not good at anything, but in a lot of things
content:
One of the central aspects of interpersonal relationships. Even with yourself. It’s very powerful to be vulnerable. Truely honest, truely “there”, in this very moment for this very person. You’ll feel everything: youself, a certain fear, a certain excitement. What’s going to happen next?

The powerful

Vulnerability can cause the impossible. If you dare, you can love deply. It can be the motivation for your greatest challenge, can be the basis for the most intimate friendships. You show yourself, the way you are. You’re afraid, but your there regardless.

Avoidance

The opposite is the complete avoidance of vulnerability. It leads to weird relationships, odd communication that leads nowhere. It remains fleeting and trivial. You’re looking to get out of it as soon as possible, but you’re safe. You’ll stay invulnerable, yet injured. By crawling away, you’ll validate and sustain your fears. It doesn’t lead anywhere, except a weird form of security.

Always afraid, never happy, because nothing can truely be.

So be you, be vulnerable. Show yourself. That’s the how you live.

title: Quotes
description: Quotes from various people, that I liked
content: If you don’t learn, you’re a fool

title: Taking notes
description: Writing down things is a genius idea.
content: It’s an exciting process. Once you start, you’re thoughts expand. Your mind starts looking for connections, comes up with similar thoughts and ideas (see Written thoughts). It’s therapeutic, while also being exhausting. It empties your mind, might help the unraveling.

title: The broad focus
description: Not good at anything, but in a lot of things
content:
I don’t have a focus in life. Not one, maybe multiple, which sounds contradictory. There’s nothing that fascinates me enough to sink into it for the rest of the foreseeable future, like a deep passion for music where everything else is meaningless.

That’s not bad though. The question is: What do I do with it. Professionally? Personally?I would like to have something, that I’m very good at. Concepts like excellence and mastery fascinate and impress me, but I’m not sure I can achieve it.

Sometimes I find things, that fascinate me, that I do a lot and want to be good at, and then I let them go ago. Few things persist.

title: The limbo after a breakup
description: It's a weird floating state between to people.
content:
This weird floating state between to ex-lovers (please don’t generalise too much). A desire for contact, built over time, mixed with remnants of love, while trying to avoid emotions and keeping anything meaningful (topics that might hurt) out of the conversation. Sharing, but not too much. Keeping distance, but not too much. It seems like a very fragile state that needs to be upheld.

Why though? What’s there to lose?

I think it’s about vulnerability. Two ways.

On the one hand it’s a sort of self-defence against disappointment. Not hoping for things that won’t be - cannot be again, on both sides. Not getting involved in something, that might end badly.

On the other hand it’s a fear of losing someone forever. It might be out of habit. Maybe there’s something worth sustaining. A friendship, hopes, a dream. Keeping a foot in the door. Maybe you’ll need it one day.

What becomes a weird paradoxon. Not too much, not too little. Everything and nothing at the same time.

title: The observer
description: He observes
content:
He roams, he sees, he observers. Oftentimes cursory, sometimes very thoroughly. What’s he looking for? Nothing.

He’s either searching or looking to go somewhere, it’s the process. He is observing.

title: The way of the water
description: The past of least resistance is a simple one.
content:
It’s the way of my life - the path of least resistance. Opportunistic. Impossible to fight the way you are for very long. And why would you.

It feels straightforward. There is no fight. Some people try, but there’s only one path. My path.

To be, that’s the purpose.

Sometimes I need to remind myself about this, it helps.

title: (Un)conditional love
description: What is it and does it exist
content:
I think, love, or whatever it is we call love, is always conditional. This opens up a huge wormhole, but let’s keep it simple.

I think love is always tied to something: be it time, location, reciprocality, simple physical attractiveness and most of all: that the other person is the person you think you know. That could be an idealistic version, but it’s usually enough no to be disillusioned / disappointed by them. No strong break, no murder, no deception, no cheating - the usual.

And that’s it. It’s conditional, even in family (or even MORE in family.)

title: Written thoughts
description: Writing down things is a genius idea.
content:
It’s fascinating what writing down my thoughts does for me. It pulls them out of my head and lays them to rest. They’re often gone afterwards.

Can I revisit them later and pick up where I left of? I need to try that sometimes.

It’s just good for me. It calms, it clears, it categorises and creates room for other things and by thus, new things.

Even though I haven’t left many things here, I’m sure that it has helped me immensely. Emotionally, professionally, personally. It pushed me into the right directions. It also opens up a new way to share things with others.

Last but not least, it helps my writing style. I think so, anyways. I’m thinking how I write things down, sometimes delete, sometimes play with sentences. Doing that in English is different again. It’s very exciting though - It’s definitely a habit I’d like to pick up and build upon.

title: Writing style
description: It's like a personality, but in written form.
content: It’s like a personality, but in written form.
